bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jose Andreu, November 26, 1952

div1.p: Truby conveys to Andreu his deep appreciation at being honored by the Cuban government for his contribution to the yellow fever work. He is also pleased that Leonard Wood and Hanberry were included

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jose Andreu, November 26, 1952
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
November 26, 1952
Dr. Jose Andreu
El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social
Havana, Cuba
Kindness of Dr. Philip S. Hench
My dear Dr. Andreu:
div1.p:
Through Dr. Pedro Nogueira and Dr. Hench, I have heard
that my name has been included with the distinguished
names of the other persons who took some part in assist-
ing Walter Reed and the other members of his Board in
the work at Camp Lazear in 1900. Consequently, because
I could not accept your kind invitation to be present
at the dedication ceremonies on December 3, 1952, I
am asking Dr. Hench to transmit personally my deep
appreciation of the honor being paid me by the Cuban
Government in having my name appear in bronze as one
of those who contributed to the project.

The wonderful scientific experiments performed at
Camp Lazear have been more appreciated as the years
have passed and now, over fifty years later, the
recognition of the work done there and of Dr. Finlay's
persistent adherence and faith in his theory can never-
more be questioned.

I was profoundly pleased and impressed by the honors
the Cuban Government bestowed upon General Leonard Wood
and James Leonard Hanberry, the last surviving member
of Reed's volunteers, by inclusion of their names on
bronze medallions as being among the principals in this
great experiment.

The Cuban Government is to be congratulated in taking
steps at this time to preserve the “tiny caseta”
(Building Number 1 of the Reed Board) in a fitting
little park on the actual site of Camp Lazear on the
“Finca San José” at Marianao. Your tribute to all
concerned and your timely and most impressive ceremonies
will be appreciated everywhere.
Again, with my most sincere thanks,

closer.signed:
Albert E. Truby
Brigadier General
U. S. Army, Retired
